case_vignette:
A 5-year-old female presents with a plaque on her left leg. The lesion appeared a few months after her birth. It has been increasing in size proportionally to her growth. The parents mentions that the skin lesion sometimes becomes irritated, erythematous and itchy when the patient plays with it or when she gets sick. Physical exam reveals a red-brown well delimited plaque on her left leg without any noticeable erythema or epidermal changes. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other symptoms.

Physical exam reveals a red-brown well delimited plaque on their left leg without any noticeable erythema or epidermal changes. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other symptoms.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a red-brown, well-defined skin lesion on my left leg that sometimes becomes irritated, red, and itchy, especially when I play with it or when I get sick.
How long have you had this skin lesion?
The lesion appeared a few months after I was born.
Has the size or appearance of the lesion changed over the years?
Yes, it has been increasing in size proportionally to my growth.
Do you have similar lesions anywhere else on your body?
No, I don't have any similar lesions elsewhere on my body.
Have any of your immediate family members had similar skin issues?
The information provided does not include details about my family members having similar skin issues.
Has the lesion ever bled or ulcerated?
No, the lesion has never bled or ulcerated.
Final Diagnosis: Congenital Melanocytic Nevus.
